document.docTitle: Sinanapis longituba Lin & Li, 2012, new species
document.masterDocTitle: Three new spider species of Anapidae (Araneae) from China

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Three new spider species of Anapidae (Araneae) from China

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type material.—
Holotype ♂ ( IZCAS ), CHINA : Hainan : male , Qiongzhong County , Mt. Limushan Nature Reserve ( 19°11'N , 109°44'E ), elevation
655 m
,
12 August 2007
, S. Li and C. Wang .
Paratypes : 3 ♂ , 11 ♀ ( IZCAS ), same data as for holotype
.

caption.paragraph: Figure 10.—Locality records of three new Chinese anapids. 1. Gaiziapis encunensis new species ; 2. Minanapis menglunensis new species ; 3. Sinanapis longituba new species .

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology.—Specific epithet is derived from Latin ‘‘longitubus’’—long-tube, referring to the presence of a long process on palpal patella of male; adjective.

Diagnosis.—The new species is similar to Sinanapis crassitarsus Wunderlich & Song 1995 and S. thaleri Ono 2009 in having similar body size, strong male leg I, modified cusps on metatarsus and tarsus I, and complicated patellar apophyses in the male (Figs. 7A–D, H; 8A, B), but can be distinguished from S. crassitarsus and S. thaleri by the presence of anterior median eyes (Fig. 7E), very long and sclerotized, rather than grater-like, patellar apophysis on the palp, conical bulb with coiled embolus in the male (Figs. 8A, B). Female (unknown in S. crassitarsus and S. thaleri ) can be easily recognized by the longer than wide book lung covers and the two coiled copulatory ducts encircled by spherical spermathecae (Figs. 9A–C).
Distribution.—Known only from the type locality (Fig. 10).
